remarks: Induction on the upper integers that start at an integer ` B ` .  The first four hypotheses give us the substitution instances we need; the last two are the basis and the induction step. _Warning:  The HTML proof page is 3/4 megabyte in size.  An attempt to shorten it is on my to-do list.  Anyone is welcome to try_. (Contributed by NM, 11-May-2004.)  (New usage is discouraged.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)
statement:
uzindOLD.1 $e |- ( x = B -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
uzindOLD.2 $e |- ( x = y -> ( ph <-> ch ) ) $.
uzindOLD.3 $e |- ( x = ( y + 1 ) -> ( ph <-> th ) ) $.
uzindOLD.4 $e |- ( x = A -> ( ph <-> ta ) ) $.
uzindOLD.5 $e |- ps $.
uzindOLD.6 $e |- ( ( ( y e. ZZ /\ B e. ZZ ) /\ B <_ y ) -> ( ch -> th ) ) $.
uzindOLD $p |- ( ( ( A e. ZZ /\ B e. ZZ ) /\ B <_ A ) -> ta ) $.
$d A x $.
$d B x y $.
$d ch x $.
$d ph y $.
$d ps x $.
$d ta x $.
$d th x $.
